item.title: Bridge Owner Donated $1 Million to MAGA Group Before Trump Blasted Competitor
item.description: The PAC and the White House say the donation had nothing to do with President Trump’s tirade against a new bridge connecting Detroit and Windsor, Ontario.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Gordie Howe International Bridge under construction in Windsor, Ontario, in January 2024.

item.title: U.S. Kills 3 in Latest Boat Strike
item.description: Legal specialists on the use of lethal force have said the strikes are illegal, extrajudicial killings.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gen. Francis L. Donovan, the leader of the U.S. Southern Command, last month in Washington.

item.title: Trump Presses on With Tariffs, Posing Challenge for Republicans
item.description: The president is plowing ahead with an unpopular policy after the Supreme Court’s rebuke, deepening his party’s risk in the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We have very powerful alternatives,” President Trump declared, announcing a new 10 percent import tax. “For those who thought they had us.”

item.title: 6 Takeaways From the Supreme Court’s Tariff Decision
item.description: The court displayed its independence in what was a stinging rebuke to President Trump, though the ruling is unlikely to have an immediate effect on prices.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: In a landmark ruling, the Supreme Court on Friday invalidated many of the tariffs imposed by President Trump.

item.title: Judge Rebukes U.S. Over Application to Search Washington Post Reporter’s Home
item.description: A prosecutor apologized for failing to alert the magistrate to a 1980 law that restricts searches for reporting materials.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Erik Wemple
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Eastern District of Virginia courthouse in Alexandria, Va., on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Planes Land at Jordan Base, a Key Hub for Planning Possible Iran Strikes
item.description: At least 60 attack aircraft are parked at the base, which has become a key hub for U.S. military planning for possible strikes on Iran.
item.dc:creator: Riley Mellen, Christoph Koettl and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: 64% of Americans Disapprove of Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: The poll found disapproval among men, women, all racial and ethnic groups and across educational backgrounds.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Igielnik
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Port of Seattle in Seattle.

item.title: Longtime Virginia Lawyer Chosen by Judges as U.S. Attorney, and Then Fired
item.description: It was the second time this month that the administration had gotten rid of a top federal prosecutor appointed to his post by federal judges.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

item.title: White House Dims Lights as Trump Responds to Tariff Ruling
item.description: The mood lighting appeared to be borrowing from the playbook of former President Joseph R. Biden Jr., and the old meme of “Dark Brandon.”
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at a news conference at the White House on Friday. With him were D. John Sauer, the United States solicitor general, left, and Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary.

item.title: The U.S. Tariffs Causing the Most Pain for Canada Remain in Place
item.description: While the vast majority of Canadian exports were exempt from the tariffs now struck down, the ruling does not effect duties harming several key industries.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Carlos Osorio/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada toured Algoma Steel last year in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

item.title: Ask The Morning: The Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.description: The justices struck down a central piece of President Trump’s agenda. What does that mean?
item.dc:creator: the staff of The Morning

item.title: A.I. Is Coming for the 2026 Midterms
item.description: Our tech columnist Kevin Roose explains A.I.’s potential impact.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Dado Ruvic/Reuters
item.media:description: Artificial intelligence companies have an increasingly important role in American politics.

item.title: Melania Trump Presents Her 2025 Inaugural Gown to the Smithsonian
item.description: The dress joined an exhibit of gowns belonging to first ladies stretching back to Helen Taft in 1909, and Mrs. Trump spoke about how high fashion reflected humanity.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Because President Trump was elected to nonconsecutive terms, Melania Trump will have two gowns in the collection.

item.title: ‘A Disgrace’: How Trump Found Out the Supreme Court Ruled Against Him
item.description: The news arrived in a note passed by the U.S. trade representative.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump speaking to governors at the White House on Friday.

item.title: C.I.A. Retracts Reports Flagged for Bias
item.description: Former officials said the documents were not examples of shoddy work and simply reflected the priorities of past administrations.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Ratcliffe, the C.I.A. director. The agency’s leadership has made moves to keep in step with President Trump.

item.title: After Tariff Decision, What Happens to Trump’s Deals With China, Canada and Europe?
item.description: The Supreme Court’s decision to invalidate many of President Trump’s tariffs raised questions about what would become of agreements struck with major U.S. trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher, Meaghan Tobin, Eshe Nelson, Alexandra Stevenson, River Akira Davis, Alex Travelli, Choe Sang-Hun, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump signed a trade deal with Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi of Japan in Tokyo in October.

item.title: Tariff Whiplash Clouds Outlook for Federal Budget
item.description: The tariffs thrown out by the Supreme Court had become an important revenue source. President Trump said he could replace that money with other levies.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren

item.title: Bench Presses, Pull Ups … Kid Rock? The White House Had a Very Manly Week.
item.description: President Trump’s top cabinet officials are pumping iron in public.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers

item.title: Trump blasts the tariff ruling on Truth Social.
Even After Supreme Court Ruling, Trump Insists He Can Do as He Wishes
item.description: President Trump showed open contempt for the court, calling the justices who voted against his tariffs “fools and lap dogs.” He quickly imposed new levies using legal powers still available to him.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump in the James S. Brady Briefing Room at the White House on Friday. With him are the United States solicitor general, D. John Sauer, left, and the commerce secretary, Howard Lutnick.

item.title: Some Republicans Laud Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling, Reflecting Intraparty Angst
item.description: While President Trump’s staunchest supporters condemned the decision, some Republicans suggested it restored Congress’s rightful role in weighing in on trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Chuck Grassley, Republican of Iowa, at the Capitol earlier this month. Mr. Grassley applauded the Supreme Court decision, but also said he supported President Trump’s efforts to negotiate expanded market access for American products.

item.title: After Supreme Court Loss, Trump Plans to Impose Global Tariffs Using Different Laws
item.description: The administration has been preparing for months for the possibility that the Supreme Court would rule against the president and developed contingency plans.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Using different legal authorities, President Trump plans to impose a 10 percent global tariff and open investigations into certain, unspecified countries’ unfair trade practices.

item.title: The Supreme Court’s Declaration of Independence
item.description: The court’s rejection of President Trump’s tariffs program is the latest in a series of clashes between him and Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. wrote the majority opinion against President Trump’s tariffs on Friday.

item.title: Supreme Court Ruling Could Dash Trump’s Spending Dreams
item.description: Tariff revenue was always unlikely to be sufficient to cover the cost of his raft of promises, but the president still seemed to describe it as essentially limitless.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump claimed that he could use tariff revenue to pay for at least 11 federal government policies or programs, a Cato Institute tracker found.

item.title: The Trade Statutes Trump Will Use to Keep Imposing Tariffs
item.description: The Supreme Court ruling is a blow, but the administration has other trade tools at its disposal.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Trucks backed up to the U.S. side of the World Trade bridge border crossing in Texas late last year.

item.title: Apple Is One of the Companies Hit Hardest by Tariffs
item.description: The company makes almost all of its products in countries facing steep levies, running up a tariff bill of $3.3 billion over the past three quarters.
item.dc:creator: Kalley Huang
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and Apple’s chief executive, Tim Cook, in the Oval Office last year announced Apple’s pledge of $100 billion in additional investment in the United States.

item.title: Trump says he’s considering a limited strike on Iran to force a deal.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald Trump at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Tariff Decision May Unleash Short Term Chaos, Dissenting Supreme Court Justices Say
item.description: The trio warned of immediate chaos over refunds and trade deals. They also provided President Trump with a list of other possible avenues for imposing tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court in Washington, D.C. earlier this year.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow, Tyler Pager, Ana Swanson and Tony Romm

item.title: What are tariffs?
item.description: The Supreme Court will hear arguments about presidential power to impose tariffs. But what are they?
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shipping containers stacked at a port in Wuhan, China. Tariffs apply to products imported from other countries.

item.title: In Ukraine, Senators See War’s Impact and Press for Stronger U.S. Support
item.description: Senate Democrats traveled to Kyiv and Odessa to show solidarity with the war-torn nation and make the case that the United States should do more, including imposing harsh sanctions on Russia.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Robert Jimison/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, on a tour of the Darnytsia power plant in Kyiv, Ukraine, which was damaged in a Russian attack this month.

item.title: Before the ruling, companies raced to secure refunds from tariffs they had paid.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: A ruling against President Trump could force his administration to pay back the roughly $200 billion it has collected in duties since the start of the year.

item.title: What is IEEPA, the Law Trump Used to Levy Tariffs?
item.description: The 1977 law gives the president broad economic powers during a national emergency.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump used the International Emergency Economic Powers Act in April to levy tariffs on almost every country in the world. He also used it in February to impose tariffs on Mexico, Canada and China.

item.title: Supreme Court Justices Strike Down Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: President Trump was the first to invoke the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 to set tariffs on imported goods from more than 100 countries.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The tariffs case reached the Supreme Court after three lower courts concluded the taxes were unlawful.

item.title: As Trump Considers Second Iran Attack, It Could Be Deadlier Than the First
item.description: Within days of the U.S. strikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities last year, all sides agreed to a cease-fire. This time could be different.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A missile display at a celebration in Tehran this month.

item.title: South Texas Democrats Will Steer Party’s Direction, Left or Center
item.description: Like many Democratic primaries, the fight for the right to challenge a Republican House member in the Rio Grande Valley comes down to a choice, shift left or choose the party’s favorite for November.
item.dc:creator: Edgar Sandoval
item.media:credit: Gabriel V. Cárdenas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters in McAllen, Texas, came to the historical Cine El Rey to see Ada Cuellar, who is running in the Democratic primary for the city’s House district.

item.title: Why the United States Is Seeing an Ongoing Tourism Slump
item.description: Last year, the U.S. was the only major destination to see a decline in international travelers. With increased scrutiny at the border, ICE violence and unpredictable policies, the new year isn’t looking better.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeğinsu
item.category: Disney, Walt, World (Lake Buena Vista, Fla)
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Passengers and crew walk to a Transportation Security Administration security checkpoint at Los Angeles International Airport in November.
